name: Stanley Kubrick
description: Obsessive perfectionist. Cold precision masking deep emotion. From war to space to horror, every frame a painting that stares back at you.

name: Akira Kurosawa
description: The Emperor. Samurai epics, Shakespearean tragedy, and humanism so profound it transcends language. Influenced every filmmaker who came after.

name: Alfred Hitchcock
description: The Master of Suspense. Voyeurism, paranoia, blonde women in peril. He didn't just make thrillers — he invented the grammar of fear.

name: Martin Scorsese
description: Mean streets, goodfellas, and the dark soul of America. No one films violence, guilt, and redemption with more ferocity or tenderness.

name: Francis Ford Coppola
description: The Godfather trilogy, Apocalypse Now, The Conversation. When he aimed for the moon, he hit it — and changed cinema forever.

name: Andrei Tarkovsky
description: Time sculpted in light and water. The most spiritual filmmaker who ever lived. Each film a meditation that demands surrender.

name: Ingmar Bergman
description: Death plays chess, God stays silent, and love is the only answer that isn't enough. The philosopher-poet of cinema's deepest questions.

name: Federico Fellini
description: Dreams made flesh. Carnival grotesques and tender romantics inhabit a cinema so personal it became its own adjective: Felliniesque.

name: David Lynch
description: Don't try to understand it. Feel it. Suburban nightmares, industrial drones, and the sinister beauty hiding behind every white picket fence.

name: David Fincher
description: Meticulous, obsessive, relentless. Dark rooms and darker truths. Every cut, every shadow, every sound designed to unsettle.

name: Paul Thomas Anderson
description: Epic American tapestries woven from loneliness, ambition, and yearning. From Boogie Nights to There Will Be Blood — sprawling, intimate, and unmistakable.

name: Denis Villeneuve
description: Quiet devastation and staggering scale. From intimate thrillers to sci-fi epics, he makes the impossible feel tactile and the human feel cosmic.

name: Christopher Nolan
description: Time as puzzle, spectacle as philosophy. The blockbuster auteur who proved you can bend audiences' minds and break box office records simultaneously.

name: Bong Joon-ho
description: Genre-smasher. Social satirist. The man who made the whole world watch a Korean film about stairs. Every movie a Trojan horse of ideas.

name: Park Chan-wook
description: Vengeance as art form, violence as ballet. Baroque, romantic, and absolutely savage — cinema that grabs you by the throat and doesn't let go.

name: Wong Kar-wai
description: Heartbreak in neon. Cigarette smoke and slow motion. The loneliest, most beautiful films ever made about love that almost happened.

name: Hayao Miyazaki
description: The master of animated cinema. Ecological fables, flying machines, and childhood wonder rendered with a hand-drawn beauty that no algorithm can replicate.

name: Wes Anderson
description: Symmetrical frames, pastel palettes, and melancholy hiding behind whimsy. A miniaturist whose dollhouse worlds contain real, aching hearts.

name: Joel Coen
description: America's greatest filmmaking duo. Fargo, No Country, The Big Lebowski. Dark comedy, darker philosophy, and dialogue sharp enough to cut glass.

name: Sofia Coppola
description: Isolation as aesthetic. Lost in Translation, The Virgin Suicides, Marie Antoinette. Loneliness has never looked so luminous or sounded so good.

name: Steven Spielberg
description: The most commercially successful director alive who is also a genuine artist. From Jaws to Schindler's List, he defined what movies can make you feel.

name: Billy Wilder
description: The greatest screenwriter-director who ever lived. Sunset Boulevard, The Apartment, Some Like It Hot. He invented modern comedy and noir in the same career.

name: Orson Welles
description: Citizen Kane at 25. He invented modern filmmaking, then spent the rest of his life fighting the system he'd outgrown. Every shot a revolution.

name: Ridley Scott
description: A visual architect whose films defined entire genres. Alien, Blade Runner, Gladiator — each one a world so complete you can smell the air.

name: Terrence Malick
description: The most singular poetic voice in American cinema. Whispered narration, golden-hour light, and a camera that moves like prayer through a broken world.

name: Pedro Almodovar
description: Spain's greatest living filmmaker. Melodrama, desire, and identity in technicolor. All About My Mother, Talk to Her, Volver — passion as a way of life.

name: Spike Lee
description: Do the Right Thing. Malcolm X. BlacKkKlansman. An essential American voice — fiery, inventive, politically unafraid, and cinematically restless.

name: Werner Herzog
description: The madman of world cinema. Aguirre, Fitzcarraldo, Grizzly Man. He drags cameras into places no sane person would go, and brings back truth.

name: Sergio Leone
description: He didn't just make westerns — he turned them into opera. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly. Once Upon a Time in the West. Cinema as myth.

name: Michael Mann
description: The poet laureate of nocturnal cities. Heat, Collateral, The Insider. Obsessive professionals, digital gunfire, and Los Angeles at 2 AM.

name: Yorgos Lanthimos
description: The most important European auteur of the last decade. The Lobster, The Favourite, Poor Things. Absurdist, unsettling, wickedly funny, and brilliant.

name: Abbas Kiarostami
description: The towering figure of Iranian cinema. Taste of Cherry, Close-Up, Certified Copy. Simple surfaces hiding infinite philosophical depth.

name: Lars von Trier
description: Love him or hate him, he's essential. Melancholia, Dancer in the Dark, Breaking the Waves. A provocateur who makes you feel things you'd rather not.
